Widespread controversy occurred in 1984 when famed neo-Nazi and member of the Satanic cult O9A, Geoffry Magnum, (often referred to by his self-proclaimed nickname Bongwarrior) attacked the members of Cale Donk, attempting to kill them with a pocket knife. The members of Cale Donk fought Bongwarrior off until authorities arrived and apprehended him, whereupon threats of "deleting" the members were issued.

Kek

"@Evident Disaster":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53faed85636872197a920100#post_53faed85636872197a920100
IF it gets bad enough I wouldn't be surprised if this is what happens.  The only options still left on the table are A)close down all transportation to Africa and let it burn itself out resulting in a fuck ton of deaths but saving countless others B)start bombing.

I was going to make a long post, but essentially here's the terrifying thing: no one is taking option b off the table.  Sure it's getting dismissed and such as ludicrous and such but no one has taken it off the table yet; it's still very much on the table.

topics.body:
"@Albus Fahrenheits":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53faf73c6368720b732e0100#post_53faf73c6368720b732e0100
Call me weird but honestly I hope for the health of people regardless.  What I mean by this is that even if someone "deserves" to die I would still do my best to help them regardless.  I still wish them well.

Sure the ebola outbreak if it reaches the middle east could solve the ISIS situation, but it would kill numerous innocent people that had nothing to do with it and were just unlucky to be at the wrong place at the wrong time.  The tens of thousands of people that very well could become infected in the next couple of months for the vast majority don't deserve to die and yet they will die anyhow not cause they did anything wrong.  That's just how the world works in that countless people that did nothing wrong die and merely die because they were in the wrong place at the wrong time, but that doesn't mean you stop caring.

Honestly I have seen people die; I think the most brutal death I've seen was someone literally splattered all over the place, the second most brutal as a car crash, but that didn't stop me from caring about people to be honest.  If anything it made me realize that you should care about others.  It's easy to clam up and go "fuck you got mine" but it's much harder to continue to care about people even when you can't do anything to help them.  Often times there are sick people dying that you can't do anything about and often times it's someone personal, but it's much harder to continue to care when you see them slowly die in the most horribly painful ways imaginable and knowing you can't do anything to help them.  It doesn't get any easier watching people die no matter how much a person clams up and no matter how many you see people die, but it's much harder to continue to care.



I'll see everyone Tuesday cause I need to get some sleep and chances are by the time I wake up the internet will be off.
